The "Broadcast Ownership for the 21st Century Act" amends the Communications Act of 1934 by adding a new section that revises duopoly rules. The Commission is limited in prohibiting ownership of two stations with overlapping coverage contours in separate television markets or two television stations within the same market, with one being a UHF station. Existing local marketing agreements between two broadcast television stations in the same market are protected. The Broadcast Ownership for the 21st Century Act amends duopoly rules, protecting existing local marketing agreements between broadcast television stations in the same market. The Commission may allow ownership of two VHF stations in exceptional circumstances. The Broadcast Ownership for the 21st Century Act allows ownership of two VHF television stations in the same market under exceptional circumstances, if it does not harm competition or media diversity. SEC. 3. CROSS-OWNERSHIP LIMITATIONS. The Federal Communications Commission will modify regulations to eliminate restrictions on granting or renewing broadcast station licenses based on ownership of a daily newspaper and remove the one-to-a-market rule. The Federal Communications Commission will modify regulations to eliminate restrictions on granting or renewing broadcast station licenses based on ownership of a daily newspaper and remove the one-to-a-market rule. Additionally, the Commission will not consider a minority voting stock interest as a cognizable interest if a single holder owns more than 50 percent of the voting stock. Cable cross-ownership limitations under the Communications Act of 1934 will also be amended. The Federal Communications Commission will revise regulations to allow ownership of a broadcasting station and a cable system in the same community. Additionally, dual-network rules for television broadcast stations will be updated. The Federal Communications Commission will revise regulations to allow a television broadcast station to affiliate with a person or entity maintaining two or more networks, with certain restrictions on interconnected program services. The Federal Communications Commission will revise regulations to allow television broadcast stations to affiliate with multiple networks offering interconnected program services for at least 15 hours per week to affiliated licensees in multiple states.
